title: ArmaTweet: Detecting Events by Semantic Tweet Analysis
segmentation: Thank you for this introduction and thank you for attending my talk so.
This talk is about an industrial collaboration between the two universities and Arma Swiss, who.

Are essentially an R&D agency for the Swiss Armed Armed Forces, and in particular they were looking at Twitter, so we all know Twitter so quite a lot of users produce quite a lot of tweets on a daily basis.
Quite a lot of this.
Let's face it, junk, but there is quite a lot of useful information, especially about current events.
If you think about like terrorist activity or so on.
So for example, on the Brussels attack on on the 23rd of March in 2016 was well documented.
Here are some examples.

Tweets that people treated as the events were happening actually and then, for example during the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, again quite a lot of tweets were generated, and now the idea of Arma Swiss, which is not by itself novel, was to see can we somehow use this information?
This publicly publicly available information.
Most of the Twitter feeds are actually publicly accessible, so you can just go and analyze them.
Can we use it to either maybe more quickly identify these?

Events as they are happening more quickly than the actual media so that you can respond to it and then actually during the course of this project there was another use case so some events are kind of you miss them initially there maybe not even reported in the media, but you could actually be interested in them, so you might want to detect them retroactively.
And they were already so before this project started, they were already developing a social media analysis system, which essentially just ingested two years of tweets.

Twitter offers this 1% stream API which gives you about 1% of tweets that are published on a daily basis, and they've been recording these tweets since it's started essentially, and they index them by keywords.
But then obviously they wanted to do a bit more, and I'll explain exactly what was missing in the existing.
System so, but before we proceed to what we actually did I will tell you a little bit about the state of the art, because obviously we weren't the first ones to think.
Like, hey, you know Twitter could be useful for detecting events, so we looked into the literature and in the literature you can usually find three kinds of similar approaches.
Unspecified events, predetermined events and specific events.
So if you.
About unspecified events, these are approaches that essentially do some kind of tweet clustering, so they look at.
You know that they identified trends.
They look at, you know what kind of stuff are people mostly talking about, and then they basically identify.
OK, here is a topic that could seem interesting, so they're not geared towards any specific kind of event.
Essentially then, for example, some of these approaches.
They also identify the type of event, so you have, maybe you know.
15 predefined categories and they tried to classify events into these categories.

And here is an example of 1 very prominent system from that group for January and the cabin you can see the Charlie Hebdo attacks here, but you will see later there are events which for example, harmacy Arma, Swiss identified as important and interesting but they are nowhere nearly mentioned here.
And actually if you look at most of it I mean OK, Charlie Hebdo attacks.
They were so important that people really.
Tweeted about them, but if you look at the rest it's you know, pretty much gibberish.
I mean most of it is about celebrities.
You know, Justin Bieber and something like this.
Then

You've got the predetermined events, so there is a lot of there has been a lot of work or you know you build a system for detecting one specific event type, and here is just a list of some types of events that we found in the literature like earthquakes, natural disasters, disease progressions, festivals, concerts.
You know whatever you wish, basically.
Now these systems they don't take any input from the user as to what kind of event would you like to detect.

The system is specifically built for whatever the designers put into it, and they typically use some combination of NLP, then some machine learning and a lot of domain knowledge about these events in order to actually build a system that detects these kind of events, and they're very successful on their event type, but they're not very general, so you can't actually put.
Security analyst in front of such a system and say, OK, I'd like to, for example, be interested.
I'm interested in deaths of politicians, which was actually something that Armathwaite Armas Swiss found this interesting.
So if you wanted actually to go for a different event, you would need to reprogram or even retrain the system.
And then you have specific events, so this is essentially you have your.

You know this is your typical Google like system where you can basically describe in some way the event is you're interested in and currently all existing systems do some form of information retrieval.
So keyword search maybe with some form of keyword expansion, and that seems to work very well.
So for example if you wanted to see Charlie Hebdo shootings, so this is a snapshot of this MA system developed by Armys we so there.
Previous version the new UI looks a bit different and if you look for hostage shooting or Paris you see that those are really one of the most frequent words on that day.
So you could do a keyword search.
But the point is, you have to know in advance that there's going to be shooting in Paris and then you search for Paris basically.
So the problem is essentially what kind of keywords do you put into this system.
And then, as I say, we looked into various kinds of events that are more Swiss, would be interested in, and one of them was.
You know, deaths of politicians, births of royalty, or you know various kinds of these kinds of events.
And we had this politician dying.
And then, you know, this is what happens if you put politician and die as a keyword query into Twitter's public API.
This is what you get.
So we get a bunch of tweets which mention politician and I and you know, none of them really talk about politicians dying.
The problem is obviously that most of you know the word die.
People use it in all sorts of different contexts.
And also I mean, they don't usually say such and such person was a politician and he died.
You know they would just mention such and such person person and this is what you get if you say politician or die, you get even more junk essentially.
So this is the state of the art.
So the goal of our work was to extend this SMS system with semantic event detection.

So the objective was, you know you have all these tweets, but it's very difficult to find the signal inside this and you're not interested in, you know Justin Bieber or whatever you're interested in very specific kinds of events which constitute only a tiny fraction of what you have on the day essentially.
So the key to this was to be able to precisely describe events of interest.
And what does this actually mean?
So you would like to say, OK, who does what, to whom and where?
For example, who could be a politician?
What he dives?
Who could be a militia group but performs an act of violence?
Or, for example, you could have a combination of what and to whom so?
So what performs the cyber attack 2 some company?

So there was a lot of discussion here because actually in the project team some people were more IRL oriented and they're not used to this idea of precisely specifying something, so they were like, OK, I just don't want to write semantic queries for this.
You know, you know I should be able to.
System should be able to kind of find the query for me.
Well, I mean that's a feature, not a bug.
Took me a lot of time to really convince them that this is what we should be doing.
In the very least, we just wanted to test whether this is something that users would you know, but that would work basically.
So, for example, there is this guy, Edward Brooke.
Here was the first African American senator who died on the 3rd of January 2015, and only about 1000, maybe 2000 tweets on that.
They talk about his death essentially, so his death is detectable from this mass of tweets on the day, but unspecified.
Techniques have no chance becausw you know this is just not going to register among this noise of you know whatever you find there and you have to have a way to really focus the search.
And as I've shown you, keyword search is not precise enough 'cause we don't understand relationships.
So the main idea was to use semantic search, so.
The idea was essentially to look at these tweets and we will annotate them automatically with quads, whereas these I don't use this as RDF quads.

Don't think of this as RDF courts that just the conceptual object I invented, so a quart basically says, you know you have a subject, predicate and object and a location in any of these components can be absent.
So for example, in the case of politicians dying, the subject will be the politician in question.
The predicate will be the verb to die and the rest is irrelevant actually.
So the idea is you basically turn this tweet into tweets.
This mass of tweets into a knowledge base.
And then you embed these tweets into knowledge graph where we use DB pedia as background knowledge about nouns.
So it provides anchors for subjects, objects and location quite well.
Actually it provides you with classification.
So in DB pedia you can find information that Edward Brooke was a politician.
You can provide containment hierarchy like Burns in Switzerland.
You can provide all sorts of background information that can help you construct your semantic queries and then we used word NET.

Is background knowledge about verbs cause that we used to match predicates and then the general idea was to describe events of interest using queries over this knowledge graph and this is just an English paraphrasing of, for example one query.

So select quads where subject is classified as a politician and predicate refers to dying and then this will identify tweets in question which you might want, which possibly talk about the event of interest.
And then you still.
So what you get out of this is what we call a time series, which is essentially number of tweets per day which were identified according to this query.
And then you still have to somehow filter out the signal from the noise, and for this we use statistical Time series analysis.
So once when you get this number of tweets per day, then you actually look at is this a real event or not?
So in the rest of my talk, I'm going to describe very.
This components of this approach here is the schematic architecture.
So what we do is you have a bunch of tweets which are then first passed through an NLP stack whose goal is to essentially output these quotes and that was the domain of the people from freebore.
Then you know you put your event categories, which are essentially your queries which define how quads are you interested in.
You put that into the Knowledge Graph which combines this quotes with DBPR in Word net.
That spits out these time series, which is essentially a sequence of date, number of tweets, date, number of tweets, and then you do event detection in the end using time series analysis.
And so this part was obviously us in this part.
Was Arma Swiss so?
So what the system outputs is a list of events where each event has a summary, so you don't get just OK.
There was an event, but you can actually get the semantic description out of each event.
For example, Edward Brooke dies.
This is an event of type politician dying.
But there is a caveat so far.
We each event is associated with only one day, so we it was a bit difficult to find queries that would identify long running events like the Ebola disease progression or something like that.
So you know, for the moment if something keeps happening over days, you get an event on every single day, and this is obviously something for future work.
So what I'm going to do?
Next I'm going to just briefly survey.
I'm not going to go into the details, I'll just briefly survey various components of the system so.
The natural language component.
Its goal is to take a tweet and turn it into a bunch of quads.
And the way we do it is actually relatively simple, so we use open IE, which is the central P tool to pro.
So first there is some simplification cleaning up, removing emojis and so on, and then we use open IE to essentially convert a tweet into these kinds of other call text triples.
So they're already sort of talking about relationships, but they're really strings, so it's triples of strings, and we meet here.
Essentially, you arise and so on.
So already a good first step, but the problem is not just to now resolve this, I mean it turned out that this output of open IE wasn't very clean, in particular.
For example, we wanted to identify location of various actions and for this you also get the parse tree out of this tool and then you can do some kind of pattern matching on the parse tree.
I'm not going to go into the details, but essentially if you see a specific pattern grammatical pattern essentially in the sentence.
Then you can say OK, this object is not actually the object of the action, but the location of the action.
It's like an adverb essentially, so you can move this into the location part of the quad.
Then another thing which was actually quite difficult is that this tool wasn't very good at identifying passive voice.
So again some kind of grammatical pattern matching on this parse tree here and then you can actually flip around the object and the subject and hopefully correct the passive voice.
In the sentence.

I mean, I'm not going to go into the details.
The whole point of this is that you know what we want to do is we want to create a new.
Individual in this knowledge base called the time series for a specific query, which then collects all quads.

Sorry all tweets which correspond to that object type, so that is also gets then put into this knowledge graph and then you can in the end just query the knowledge graph for these time series and get back the tweets of interest.

These queries gets turned into rules which basically you know this is already a Fox syntax.

Again, I don't want to go into the details, but here for example what we did is.

So again, if you really want to look for a quote politician dying, you'll find only few of those basically, and then in quite a lot of cases this NLP is not going to be able to the structure of the sentence will be such that the NLP won't necessarily catch this semantic relationship.
So then we had a dilemma.
We could either be more precise, in which case we just got a few tweets, which wasn't good.
Or detection, or we could be less precise and say, OK, you know almost like keyword search basically.
So if you find politician and dying output something, but that wasn't good either.

'cause you know, OK, you hate.
